text: Nitro draft @ Unos Neshaminy. Pours semi-opaque nut brown with a creamy, bone-colored head. Nutty aroma mixed with a pleasant vanilla note. Medium body with a bit of creaminess and a dry finish. Nutty malt flavor mixed with a note of vanilla. Maybe a touch of tobacco at the base.

Tasted from can. Pours a clear brown with off white head. Aroma of cocoa, vanilla and some coffee. Flavors of vanilla up front with more muted chocolate and coffee notes. Very well done sessionable brown. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Whole Foods PM. Poured hazy dark brown with tan head. Earthy brown malts and vanilla in the nose. Tasted like a maduro brown ale, with the earthy, malty notes, mild tobacco, nuts, and well integrated vanilla.

12 oz. can shared by Chalumeaux, much thanks! Deeper brown in color, lasting head retention. Nice smooth, easy vanilla aroma. The flavor is mostly vanilla bean with a nutty malt base. The texture and mouthfeel is correct for the style. Carbonation is correct with a average mouthfeel. Lots of lingering vanilla on the finish. Nice.
Poured from can thanks Dchmela dated 8/23/16 light ice tea color with a light tan head. Aromas of caramel malt vanilla. Taste is smooth and creamy nicely done.

Draft at Beer Culture. 
Dark brown, creamy, lasting head. Sweet roast and vanilla aroma and flavor. Very smooth, creamy, almost silky mouthfeel.

On tap at Hops and Pie poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of cocoa, vanilla and light coffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of cocoa, vanilla and caramel with a smooth lingering vanilla cocoa finish.
Tap at Blarney. Black pour, one finger brown head. Vanilla, oak, malt, coffee aroma and taste. Light-medium body. Smooth and simple. Refreshing and a great drinker.
Can via trade. Dark brown. Smells fantastic. Vanilla, toffee and nuts. Taste is dense and creamy. Malt is thin but with a delicious candy corn and camillla flavor. Nice
12oz can to snifter. Brown of course. Creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt. Tastes of chocolate with a sweet vanilla finish.
On tap at TJs. Nitro. Poured a dark brown color with an off white head. Vanilla, chocolate, caramel, and some roast. Yep, there is vanilla in there.
Dark brown pour with a nose of chocolate, vanilla and coffee. Taste follows with a nice vanilla note. Not too sweet which is nice. Little hop bite on the finish. Great drinking beer.

Draft @ Brewery. Nitro. Pours a very dark brown, blackish beer with a creamy, nitro off white head on top. Aroma has hints of coffee and vanilla, some roasted malts and molasses. Flavor is sweet, loads of vanilla in there but the base beer is also noticeable in the palate. Nicely balanced, longlasting flavor, nice beer.

Thanks Dchmela! Pours a dark brown with tan head. Beautiful vanilla, nut, and brown sugar aromas. Flavours are crème brulee, marshmallow, vanilla, burnt sugar, toasted malts. Up there with the best brown ales Ive had.

12oz can. 8/23/16 can date. Appearance: Deep brown, nearly opaque, with some ruby hints of clarity under light. Moderate khaki head. 
Aroma: Toasted, nutty malt with a strong vanilla bean. Very nice. 
Taste: Rich toasty malt sweetness with some nutty, almost toffee character, with a moderate creamy vanilla bean character from start to finish. Sorry end the roasty edge of the malt with a low perceived bitterness. 
Mouthfeel: Medium to heavy bodied with a distinct creaminess and low carbonation. Velvety. 
Finish: Warm toasted and light roast maltiness with a creamy vanilla lingers after the swallow. 
Overall: Remarkably smooth, creamy, balanced beer. The vanilla smoothed any edges on the toasty, roasted malt, producing a smooth experience throughout. Great take on an already great Brown Ale
On tap. Dark brown in color with small creamy white head. Aroma is roasty caramel malt. Sweet flavor with vanilla notes. Medium bodied and good.

Served on tap at the brewery. Medium brown color, medium off white head. Mild vanilla and malt aroma. Medium body with a creamy texture and a sweet malt and vanilla flavor with a nice finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a nice dark brown color. Aromas of vanilla/chocolate/caramel. Flavor is smooth with a nice sweet honey chocolate taste and a little coffee bitterness.

On nitro at the Knick (4/11/15). Nice vanilla-Tootsie Roll aroma, woody with lactose. Dark black-brown with creamy off-white to tannish lacing nitro head. Medium body with nitro carbonation. Sweet but not cloying with vanilla and oatmeal, Tootsie Roll. No bitterness. Good sweet finish with lactose lingering and a mild nutty sweet after.

Pours a clear, yet very dark brown with a little reddish color and khaki colored head. Vanilla, roast, and some raw cocoa on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium bodied, very smooth and creamy. Finishes with vanilla and a chocolate linger.

Cigar City Vanilla Maduro just doesnt seem to measure up to the quality of the original. Pours a thin dark brown with no head. Only light vanilla notes in the aroma. Taste is overly vanilla flavored with a watery body. Not sure what is going on with this Vanilla Maduro, but I am hoping it was a bad pour.

Growler at home while visiting jacksonville. Pours a lightish coke colour with an off white head. Lightly milk chocolaty, light vanilla, caramel aroma. Medium body, medium carbonation. Light caramel, vanilla ice cream, light choc, hint of coffee... Smooth, sweet, easy drinking. Nice.
Brown black pour with frothy tan head and lace. Aroma is vanilla and light chocolate. Flavor is semi sweet chocolate, vanilla, and a touch of roast malt. Medium body with smooth carbonation. nice
Nitro tap at Cigar City. Aroma is vanilla, nuts, cream, cocoa, light toffee. Tastes similar. Super creamy from the nitro. Very nice and the vanilla doesnt overpower.
Cloudy brown with no head at all. Vanilla aroma is quite pleasant. Great balance in flavor and finish. Light toast, bread, and cereal. Very nice.

I've had vanilla beers that I like. Now I've had one that I don't particularly enjoy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at Mekong. Huge vanilla character on top of a nice toasty malts. Flavor more on the brown ale, toasty malts. Vanilla fades out. Smooth and creamy. Nice.

Draft at Mekong. Pours dark brown with a thin khaki head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Nice vanilla and roasted nut notes on the nose. The vanilla hits first on the tongue with the malt coming through next. Finished clean. Solid example of style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Growler. Pours opaque cola brown with a thick and frothy pale buff head; a peep of daylight gets through at the bottom. Aroma has notes of roast malt, caramel and - yes - vanilla. Toasty malt dominates the flavor but lets vanilla, caramel, and a snip of hops share the gustatory stage. Body is average, fizz is lacking; but finish is flavorful with toasty malt and vanilla notes. Try this vanilla and see if its a thrilla.
Huge vanilla here with good background of roast and light grain. Some chocolate. Dark cloudy brown pour. Light bitter finish. Thick consistency. Nice stuff. Tap at World of Beer.

Brown with a large tan head. Aroma is vanilla, roasted malt and a touch of chocolate. Flavor is strong vanilla and roasted cocoa with just a touch of coffee. Incredibly smooth and flavorful.

Wife: 3.9

I had this at Mad Pub on Nitro Tap. Pours dark brown with a off white head. Taste malt, vanilla, nutty. I thought this was good. I would drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from the tap into a pint glass.
Aroma- Great vanilla smell with malt
Appearance- Pours a brown color with a small off white head. 
Taste- Great malt and vanilla, a home run.
Palate- A medium bodied beer with mild carbonation
Overall- Another great beer from Cigar City.
On tap at the brewery. Nice vanilla touch to the base. Little bit of nutty roast. Nice.

Aroma: Mildly Roasted Malts, Sweet Vanilla

Appearance: Dark Brown Hue, Passes Mild Light, Off White Head Ring, Minimal Lacing

Taste: Vanilla, Dark Malts, Mildly Roasty

Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet
Tap. Pours a dark cola brown work a thin spotty layer of tan head. Aroma and taste of nuts, malts, and some hints of vanilla.

On tap at the cafe. cCB in Valdosta? Nice! Solid sweet brown. Cola colored. Aroma is solidly vanilla with a cocoa and oak presence as well. Lighter body with plenty of vanilla and toffee sweetness. Medium malt body, tasty.

Keg (nitro) at Cigar City Brewery, 21/02/15. 
Dark mahogany brown with a decent beige covering.
Nose is vanilla essence, toffee, biscuit, sweet notes.
Taste comprises vanilla, chocolate, toffee, light biscuit crumbkle, malt.
Medium bodied, smooth on the palate, soft mouthfeel.
Decent brown.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Anything Cigar City does from this point is a winner. Tastes like the Vanilla Porter from Breckenridge, just not as heavy. Great beer.

On tap at Rattle and Hum, NYC. Vanilla hazelnut coffee with cream aroma. Almost clear mahogany under a lasting, beige flannel blanket. Sweet vanilla and raspberry flavour with dry coffee and dried fruit accents. Moderate to low bitterness. Medium body, smooth, moderate to low carbonation.

This poured a brown color with a fluffy off white nitro head. Aroma was of vanilla, peanut butter, coffee and caramel. Flavor was vanilla upfront fading to toasted malt caramel and a surprising.g chocolate peanut butter character. Fast.
Nitro draft at Calientes in Pittsburgh. One of the best browns Ive enjoyed and possibly THE best. The vanilla is a nice added touch.
Nitro version, which gives this beer awesome look and mouth feel. It also has super pleasant vanilla aroma. Great beer.

The aroma of cocoa. The flavor is wonderful. It also consists of cocoa. Okay bitterness in the aftertaste that fills the upper part of the mouth briefly. The beer drops towards the end. Mediocre beer anyway. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.
UPDATED: APR 5, 2015 Had on nitro. Would love to try regular also. Rich vanilla, chocolate and caramel. Slight oak. Smells sweet but not spiced or sugary. Tap

Draft in nyc. Cola brown with a frothy cream head. Aroma is straight vanilla. The taste adds cocoa. Smooth nitro richness. Very good. Creamy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nitro tap @The Ginger Man, NYC.
Dark brown color, good creamy beige head. Aroma has delicious chocolate and vanilla. Nose is very strong. Medium to light-bodied, low carbonation. Vanilla and chocolate which tastes very nice - not artifical. Light but splendid.

Nitro draft at Cigar City Brewing before the RBWG 2015 welcome event. Dark brown with light tan head. Aromas of vanilla, toffee, caramel. Tastes of vanilla, caramel, toffee, milk chocolate, light roast. Medium body with a dry finish. Creamy mouthfeel. Tasty.
Draft. Pours dark brown tan head. Nose/taste of vanilla, toasty nuts, coffee and nutty malt. medium body.
Nitro draft at Khyber Pass. Dark brown pour with lots of soft tan foam. Chocolate. Vanilla. Pecans. Maple syrup. Leather. Cigars. Very smooth.

On tap at Six Ten Brewing 
Dark brown with a medium sized beige head, good lacing. Aroma of dark malts and vanilla. Flavors of vanilla, dark malts and caramel 
Nice

Pours nearly black. Small white ywt stable hwad. Smell is vanilla, sweet, clear but no overkill. Taste is thin. Vanilla, but again clear yet no overkill, slight coffee / roasty undertone with hints of chocolate. Really low carbo, id even say this is borderline cask. Together with the thin mouthfeel, it is like flavored water... Ok I guess, but not what i prefer.
Tap at Beer Authority, New York. Colour is dark brown with small slightly brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Vanilla, chocolate and malts. Pretty interesting. Could have more body.
Lots of vanilla in this one. The aroma is all vanilla with just a hint of roast malt. The flavor is similar with the vanilla taking over. Pours dark dark brown with a tan head.

On tap at Six Ten. Pours a dark brown with medium beige head that lasts. The aroma is strong vanilla and toasted malts. Thin mouth with nice roasted malt, light vanilla bean with sweet finish, very nice.

4oz on tap. Clear dark brown red color. Bigger tan head. Leaves good thicker lace. Creamy texture. Lighter body. Moderate sweet taste, lighter bitter. Smooth, kind of soft light carbonation. Awesome vanilla, nutty, chocolate. Light earthiness. Mild dark fruit. Fantastic vanilla brown ale.

Keg at the CCB tasting room. Pours clear brown with a tight, creamy beige head. Some vanilla beans in the nose, well toasted bread. Medium sweet flavor with mellow cocoa, vanilla pods, slight leafy bitterness, grainy bread. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish, some vanilla syrup, toasted bread, light toffee. Nice stuff.

Keg @ CCB. Deep brown with a fat, creamy head. Nose is of vanilla fudge, rocky road ice cream. Super sweet. Similar taste. Coffee and ashy roast malt supports a Hershey-bomb of chocolate and vanilla. Soft and smooth. Creamy. Excellent stuff in the vein of Southern Tier.

Nitro Tap at RR. Pours dark brown with slight red hew. Aroma is brown malt, vanilla beans and toasted notes. First sip is similar with some fruity aldehydes. Finish is nice a balanced with mild lingering vanilla notes. Very nice.

Draft. Pours burgundy brown with a thick white head that lingers. Mild aroma but rich vanilla flavor over this tasty brown. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On draft, pours brown with small to medium coffee head. Aromas and flavor of nuts, vanilla bean, wood, and cocoa powder. Body is medium to thick with a lasting finish.
Almost nothing not to like about this. Great base beer. Strong, but not overpowering vanilla. A little sweet.

Growler from brewery. Vanilla aroma & flavor slightly sweeter than what I typically desire but this beer still rocks. Smooth, easy to drink. Good twist on Maduro which is a wonderful brown in the first place.
Pours a clear brown with a perpetual, nitro, smooth, cream-colored head. Coffee, vanilla, and roasted malt. Mildly thick and smooth. Flavors approximate the nose.

On tap at the Brass Tap Coral Springs. Pours a nice brown with a creamy tan head and aroma of pleasant aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and vanilla. Taste is creamy, lots of great vanilla flavor throughout with chocolate and roasted malt into the nice vanilla chocolate finish. Great brew and take on the Maduro with the vanilla adding lots of flavor
This was so freaking smooth! It was like drinking a glass of silk! Great aroma. Taste was great as usual but didnt get quite as much vanilla as I would like.

On tap at Brass Tsp, Coral Springs with Audrie, pours a brown color with a creamy small java head. Noae is sweet rich vanilla malt. Taste is smooth and velvety , with rich sweet vanilla, and some subtle bitterness. Finish is smooth and dry and ends on the same tasting notes. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Draft. nitro. Pour is dark brown. Small off white head. Some chocolate and roast, vanilla, in the nose. Taste is lightly roasty, creamy, some chocolate, slight vanilla flavor. Ok. Vanilla is a nice addition but seems to thin out the beer just a touch.
On nitro. Semisweet, light chocolate and roast, vanilla, smooth. Dark brown pour with the thick creamy light tan head. Roasty, creamy, light chocolate, slight vanilla flavor.
Cask. Brown colour, no head. Sweet, malty, caramel, vanilla, low carbonation

Big stiff head on a clearish chestnut beer. Sweet, choconilla, earthy malt aroma. Woody, sweet, tannic, strong vanilla tones. Woody aftertaste, but the vanilla starts to cling. Usual Maduro body. On tap, Proof Production Facility w/PorterPounder.
Pours dark with thick creamy head. Maltyish aroma. Creamy, vanilla brown ale taste. With faint smoky finish.

On tap at Kickbacks in Jacksonville. (from May 2011 notes)

A - essentially opaque with mahogany highlights. Has a thin bubbly tan head. 

S - Sweet aroma with a clear but not too strong vanilla note; hint of milk chocolate.

T - Largely follows the aroma, but the vanilla is too dominant and the beer is too sweet. Roasted malt and oatmeal are detectable. 

M - Near medium body but too thin for style. Would also be better with a slight increase in carbonation. 

O - Disappointing: I prefer the regular Madura.
On tap at brewery. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma is all vanilla, some malt sweetness. Taste is smooth, vanilla, chocolate, tasty as hell.
Tap at the brewery... Deep hazy brown... Thin tan lacing... Sift fruits... Sift chocolate... Big berry fruits.. Soft vanilla
Tap at ccb, tampa. Clear dark reddish brown color, white head. Aroma is little roasty, fruity, malty. Nice sweet fruity body, little smoky? roasty.

Sample at the tap room. Pours a cloudy dark brown color with a thin beige head that recedes quickly to an outer ring. Small patches of lacing. Aroma of vanilla and roasted malt. Light-bodied with flavors of vanilla, chocolate malt and roasted nuts. The finish is sweet with a vanilla and malt aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

Surprisingly good. Aged on vanilla beans instead of jus vanilla added and you can tell. The vanilla flavor is infused throughout the beer. It's not subtle but its not nearly as overpowering as I expected. Not a huge maduro fan, but this was good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tallahassee, Fl - Fermentation Lounge - on tap. Dark brown pour, nice active nitro induced pour, thick khaki colored head. Aroma has some nice toffee notes, a hint of chocolate. Flavor is nice and mellow with some definite vanilla sweetness, some bittersweet chocolate mixed in and a hint of biscuit-like sweetness. Mouthfeel is a bit thinner than expected.

Tap at CCB. Smell a great amount of vanilla. Pours nice brown with some head that is off white. Taste vanilla, oak, hops, and mild wood. This is a smooth beer because of the nitro and it is very drinkable.

Maduro is good but needs a kick to amp up the flavors. Vanilla is a good choice, adding a creamy flavor and a milky effect on the tongue. Nice one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A - pours hazy orange brown.  1 finger head. S - vanilla, toffee, cream, coffee, chocolate. Dry oak & Pudding. M - light body with a dry ending. T - vanilla, toffee, caramel malts. Cheap chocolate and oak cask. O - simple sweet brown. Lightly tangy. 3.1

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hunahpus day. Brown pour with an off white head. Aroma was big time vanilla sweetness with light roasty notes. Flavors were on the sweet side with lots  of vanilla and roasted malt. Light body with average carbonation. Just ok.
Draught at the Pony Bars Cigar City Event NYC  sept 2012. Dark brown beer with a small offwhite head. Vanilla aroma. Vanilla, malty, sweet flavour. I love the clean vanilla flavour.

On tap.  Not much head, but good lacing.  Aroma was rich with notes of vanilla and maple.  Creamy on the palate, drinks very smooth.  The hints of vanilla are enough to taste, but not overpowering.  Finishes clean, with hops just discernible.  A very well balanced beer, and one that I will return to as often as I can find.

Tap at World of Beer Dr. Phillips Orlando. Dark brown with a slight head. Smooth bodied with light carbonation. Aroma of roast, chocolate, nuts, and light vanilla. Slightly sweet taste; a tad weak. Better than the standard version.

Draft sample. Cloudy brown pour, thin head, no lacing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, malts, a little vanilla extract but not much. Taste is odd - the vanilla isnt overwhelming at all, but changes the Maduro profile complely. Tastes like the CCB Double Cream Ale, really. Fairly watery too. Just okay.

Draft. Vanilla oatmeal biscuity aromas. Tastes the same as regular maduro with nice vanilla flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Kind of an ugly muddy brown pour with minimal head.  Watery vanilla with light malty notes.  Had this after a HF Twilight so the use of vanilla did not seem right in this one.   A bit too vanilly and the base beer was masked.
Draft to tulip. Looks good; a foggy brown with off-white lacing. Smells solid; vanilla and sweet malt. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. Good stuff.
Growler, heavy on the vanilla flavors, really kinda overwhelms the brown ale, oh well

Draft. Deep brown pour, tiny off-white head, no retention/lace. Aroma of chocolate, nuts, vanilla, light roast. Taste is lightly sweet, chocolate, vanilla extract, light brown sugar. Palate is soft, creamy, chocolate finish.

Sampled from the tap at the Cajun Cafe Fall Fest. Pours a hazy amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has an intense vanilla note with a bit of a cookie and dark grain backing. Flavor has some dark grain up front but has an overwhelming note of vanilla through out. Too sweet for me.
growler. thanks matt! pours brown with full khaki head. nose is brown nuts and faint vanilla. medium body and sweetnes more vanilla on the finish

On tap @ProofBrewing. Aroma is remarkably similar to the original maduro, very little vanilla present. Taste is light mix of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, with a roasted taste present as well. Still a remarkably light beer given the dark aray of flavors, and overall very pleasant. Not typically a fan of brown ales but this one was quite nice.

Pours a clear, light brown on tap with minimal tan head and light lacing. Aroma of vanilla and coffee, not a while lot else. Taste is the roasted oats, slight coffee, but mostly the synthetic vanilla. Meh.

From notes - Snifter pour deep brown/dark coffee with an off white head.  Aroma is roasted malts, sharp and crisp, notes of vanilla and coffee.  Flavor was roasted espresso, sharp malt, lingering vanilla and more coffee.  Light/Medium body - definitely good.

I had this at the brewery previously and it was very mild in the vanilla; however, these notes are from the second time I had it, which was much more enjoyable.

On tap poured dark brown, minimal head, virtually no lacing. Faint aroma of malt and vanilla. Flavor is bold vanilla with a bit of the nutty malt flavors from the original maduro. Finish is chalky, carbonation is flat. After all the hype, I was disappointed with this one.

Draught at Pony Bar, NYC. Amber/brown beer with a nice beige head. Vanilla flavor, chocolate, cocoa, fruity, grapes, hay, roasted, milk chocolate, figs, dades. Vanilla flavor, dades, cream, woody notes, banana, pine apple, bready. Sweet but still very nice.

Tap flight at the brewery. Light brown pour with minimal head. Heavy vanilla aroma. Taste is vanilla extract with softly roasted malts and enough bittering hops to  balance it a bit. Still fairly sweet from the vanilla. More mouthfeel would make this a real winner.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at the source. Murky brown color, small tan head. Aroma of - you guessed it. Taste is - you guessed it again.

Tap at CCB. Complete sheets of off white lacing atop hazy ruby. Nose is sticky vanilla cookie. Taste is super slick and oily with a thinner finish. A bit like diet cola. Soapy end. Odd. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark brown with no head, vanilla in the nose, vanilla and tobacco in the taste, very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

When this beer is on, it really is some kind of thing.  Heavy tones of vanilla but not in that "Southern Tier syrup" kind of way, sort of like an adults vanilla.  Rich but not too sweet, its definitely hard to believe this is just Maduro with some vanilla beans, it tastes almost more like a porter.

On tap at CCB.  Aroma was strong malty and vanilla.  Appearance was brown with minimal head.  Taste was sweet with the vanilla shining through.  Finish was sweet with vanilla aftertaste.  Overall a great beer from a great brewer.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 I finally got to try this beer! The body was the usual maduro; a merky brown brew with a soft white head. Aromas were pure vanilla with some nuttiness and slight roasted notes. Sip after sip reveals fresh vanilla among bready tones and a malty finish. As it warmed up the vanilla became fairly potent, and it was fantastic.

Firkin @ cigar city.  Aroma of hazelnut, cream, and a slight pot funk.  Pours pale brown with a good fast head.  Tastes of vanilla bean, dark nuts and a thin finish.  A little overbearing for its actual substance.

Really good beer. As most of the cigar city beers are just delicious!!          

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brown in color, slight haze with a thin tan head.  Big Vanilla dark roast malt aroma.  Light with hops.   This was a terrific flavored brew with great aging.  Low in alcohol most can drink a few of these for sure.

On draft at the brewery, poured a dark brown color with little head aroma of sweet malt and straight vanilla.  Flavors of light chocolate, smores, vanilla, and malt.  This is the best variety of maduro Ive had yet.

Draft at CCB. Now this is my type of maduro. Nose is malt and vanilla. Pretty simply stated the vanilla flavor adds sweetness too the aroma of the original maduro. Pours dark brown. Flavor is similar with nice, drinkable, sweet vanilla with a bit of the nutty malt flavors from the original maduro. This one is superior in my opinion. Great stuff
Draft at the brewery Christmas day. Very nice take on the maduro  brown. Provides a  great vanilla flavor that rounds out sweetness and a bold flavor addition to the regular maduro.

On draft for Cigar City Tap Takeover at Laser Wolf. Very sweet aroma of vanilla and light chocolate. As it warmed up a bit it transformed into an almost smore like beer. One hell of a tasty treat but a one and done type of beer.

Re-entering older ratings. Base reste la Maduro qui a déjà été détaillée dans mon autre revue pour cette dernière.
Un des traitements originaux de la Maduro, et où lusage de la gousse de vanille de Madagascar rajoute un aspect doux au palais ainsi que le coté caramel, malt grillé de cette brune. Les premiers batches étaient plus axé sur la vanille, cest donc cela que je note.
Cask @CCB, very drinkable.  Vanilla just goes so well with the Maduro, glad I got to try this one.  Drink this with zeal if you can get your hands on it.
on draft.  A nice twist for a brown ale.  The vanilla notes come in nice.  Very drinkable.  Keep em coming!

Tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a clear deep brown with a thin head.  Aroma is big vanilla creme chocolate candy, vanilla bean, marshmallow, nutty chocolate and tootsie roll with some light earthy burnt toffee note.  Flavor is big huge sugary candy sweetness like those big white jawbreaker candies, vanilla, slick candy syrup, then more nutty subdued earthy chocolate and tootsie roll.  Ok.

Draft at Blind Tiger.
Brown and clear, very little head. Aromas of toasty malts, vanilla is there at first but becomes much more prominent as the beer warms up. Smooth bodied with a nice vanilla finish.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 On tap with Joey Redner at Blind Tiger.  Pours a deep amber brown color with an off white foam head.  Has an aroma of vanilla, caramel, and slight roast.  Has a thin to medium mouthfeel.  Has a sweet start with a sugary caramel taste, heavy vanilla notes and a nice gentle bitter hit.  This would be a great session brew.  

1/23/2010.  On Cask from WF Bowery.  Flat and creamier than its tap bretheren.  Vanilla is a bit more subdued.
Yum.  A delicious brown ale infused with just the right amount of vanilla.  Rich brown ale flavors of honey and roasted malts with a hint of vanilla.  A really solid combination.

Draft @ Brewer: Hazy tawny hue with a nice head and average lacing. Nose of bright vanilla and chocolate, a nice dry cocoa note. Creamy malty body with tons of overpowering vanilla. Good brown ale with some nice complexity added by the vanilla. No mistaking the vanilla flavor; makes for a good single pint.

The Vanilla aged madura is more of an orange brown color. The beer has great lacing like its cocoa aged brother and is creamy with a chocolate coffee flavoring. The vanilla helps subdue the flavor of the coffee and again would be a great cooler weather beer.
Draft. This brew was sample after the regular Maduro. Pretty much the same look. The scent and taste has the smooth vanilla addition. Nice but I like the original better.

had a pint at CCB. pours a dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is light vanilla, though it tends to take over the other aroma, grainy, wood, Taste is pretty decent, the vanilla dominates with maduro on the bench. palate is pretty light with a decently smooth finish. a decent beer.

On tap, at brewery.  Pours a clear dark brown body with a one finger frothy beige head.  The nose is light vanilla, over a typical slightly sweet, nutty, and a lightly grainy base..  Huge vanilla flavor though, theres not much that makes it past the treatment.  Some slightly sweet nutty notes and toasty malt.  Medium bodied with light fizzy carbonation.  Pretty good.

Growler. Courtesy of McDiddyPop on BA. Pours a nice brown color with the slightest tinge of red to it. Great foamy tan head. The aroma is very similar to the regular version but with a strong vanilla smell that takes center stage, other notes of dark malt, subtle sweetness, cocoa take a back seat. The taste is all vanilla for the first second then slowly transitions to the roasted malt and cocoa flavors. Lingering taste of vanilla. Very well balanced. Mouthfeel is medium. An interesting addition in flavor to the regular version.
Pored brown with small head( had out of growler week old lil flat) strong vanilla and maduro taste great
Tap at CCB: Poured a brown with light brown head. Aroma is nut, oatmeal, and vanilla. Taste is upfront with a nice nutty malty flavor but leaves way for the sweet vanilla finish.

Tap at Rattle N Hum.  Deep brown pour with a thin white head.  The nose is quite nice.  Lots of soft vanilla nose up front followed by soft cocoaish character on the back.  Soft and fruity with a lingering vanilla flavour on the back.  Fairly sweet brew, but its pretty nice.

On draft at Cigar CIty. Pours dark brown with a small, off-white head. Aroma is wood, raisins, and vanilla. Flavor is burnt wood, raisins, and definately some vanilla coming through. Medium body with a bit of heat coming through. Pretty damn good beer...but thats no surprise.

Growler from the brewery. Pours brown color with red highlights and a tan head.  Roasted malt aroma with vanilla and chocolate. Similar flavor with some nuttiness also. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2010 On tap at Cigar City Brewery, vanilla and chocolate on the nose. Dark brown color with nice lacing on the glass, smooth full bodied with a nice sweet  finish. Overall impression leaves me wanting another, I enjoy the sweeter side of this beer.

Draught. Im a sucker for a brown, I must admit. same color as the regular Maduro and not so murky like the Humidor one. Aroma is hazelnut coffee, chocolate, roasted almonds, light cigar still (yes I know the cedar is gone but Im getting a little wacky Tobaccy anyways, vanilla, and a touch of molasses. Really awesome nose and not so in your face like Humidor (although I loved that too). Flavor is similar starting sweet and ending bitter wet and long.

Appearance: Pours a fairly translucent dark brown with garnet red corners. The head is a minimal 1 finger off white crown that rapidly dissipates and shows little lace.

Smell: Wow this is a nice complex one....vanilla, coffee, roast malt, caramel, a hint of spicy hops.

Taste: Take the nose and simply amplify it! Really well put together flavor profile hear. The slight touch of hops and the coffee note keep the vanilla and the caramel malt from being too sweet. They simply blend SEEMLESSLY!!!!

Mouthfeel: Fairly standard medium body with just enough carbonation. A touch thin if anything but Im being really nit picky when I say that.

Drinkability: Low abv + medium body + delicious flavor = really drinkable brew!

Serving type: growler

Reviewed on: 10-23-2009

Thanks again to HOPSHUNTER. Growler. Third one this week from that trade. Excellent carbonation. Intense vanilla aroma and taste. A brown ale kicked up as many notches as you want. Really fantastic and tasty.
Draft. Brown pour with some tan head. Vanilla, some other sugary malts, slight chocolate tones. Overall a sweetened brown ale that could be a great dessert beer.

Growler shared by DuffmanSW. Poured a dark reddish brown color with nice head. Aroma was lots of vanilla and some prunes. Taste was woody, vanilla and earthy. Pallet was medium with thick mouth feel. OVerall very good. Thanks Sean.

Growler 100cl.[ Courtesy of plovmand ]. Clear medium to dark brown color with a small, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, chocolate, nutty notes, a danish candy called "laberlaver og de orange stykke i en pose lakridskonfekt". Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, a danish candy called "laberlaver og de orange stykke i en pose lakridskonfekt". Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100409]

Huge thanks to AskDrTodd and his dad for arranging this for me.  The aroma is vanilla, chocolate, nuts, and more - it reminds me of a chocolate brownie!  The flavor is chocolate, vanilla, and obvious roasted malts as well.  The flavor is a bit harsher than the aroma via the roast, but its really not bad!

32oz growler provided by DuffManSW. Rating #89. Dark brown with a red hue to it and a light brown head that spread out fairly quickly. Aroma of chocolate and vanilla very nice. More sweet chocolate and a touch of vanilla are well represented in this one , very tasty stuff. (1197)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: The aroma of sweet vanilla soda to sum it up. The appearance is rich, dark, and clear with a creamy decent head. The flavor of vanilla and smoky notes on top of a crisp brown ale. It is very smooth, the kind you could drink for a while.

Served from a growler thanks to Caleb while waiting in line at the Veritas 007 release. The appearance is a nice amber brown with a white head. The flavors and aromas are rich with creamy vanilla, toasted malts, and a hint of caramel. The mouth was very creamy but lacked some carbonation underneath, I guess this could of been from the growler. Overall a solid brew.
Tap and growler.  Great vanilla and malt aroma, carrying over to the flavor.  There is a chocolaty/vanilla/coffee flavor that is just wonderful and creamy.

Growler via trade thanks to Sebletitje.  Glad to try another brown ale from the brewery that IMO does the style best.

Pours cloudy chestnut brown with a thick, creamy light yellow-beige head that lasts.  Good lacing.

Aroma is nice and sweet.  Lots of vanilla, along with sweet caramel, wood, and nuts.

Flavor is fairly sweet and very complex.  Caramel and toffee malt notes, chestnut and other nuts, LOADS of vanilla, wood (was this -bal aged?), chocolate, and molasses.  Crazy stuff.

Palate is exceedingly smooth and creamy, with medium-full body.  Really sticks with you.

Its almost unfair to classify this as a brown ale, but if you do, its great for the style.  Drinkable and really enjoyable overall.
Growler at Ølbutikken - Thanks Plovmand. Clear brown - offwhite head. Cocoa, vanilla, dusty cocoa, nutty, dryness, chocolate, chocofant, roasted, light body. Pleasant.

From growler, huge thanks to Plovmand for sharing. Dark brown colour. Sweet aroma of roasty malt and vanilla with caramel and some chocolate. Good pleasant mouthfeel. The flavour is sweet with toasty malt and vanilla, caramel, some chocolate and nuts. Nice brew indeed.

sampled on tap at cigar city.  Just about clear copper/brown in color with a off white head.  Aroma of fresh vanilla bean, caramel, light chocolate.  Taste has caramel/molasses with a good amount of vanilla bean flavor.  Bittering hops are light, sweetness is moderate.  Its really cool to see a brewery doing so many variations on a brown ale....a style which is perceived by alot of people (and Im guilty of this myself) as being so ordinary.

Bottle at Papsø, thanks Plovmand.
Clear orange brown coloured with a small off white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of malts, caramel, bread and hazelnuts.
Sweet flavour of caramel, bread, liquorice, hazelnuts and hops.
Hoppy finish.

Clear mahogany with a tiny beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, vanilla, caramel and toffee. Flavour had roasted malt, caramel, vanilla, toffee and chocolate notes. Finished sweet. Thanks plovmand.

Growler 100 cl. Courtesy of Plovmand. Pours a clear deep amber with a small off-white head. Rather sophisticated aroma, a little wood and nuts. Medium body, sweet vanilla beans - like the orange Malaco licorice allsorts. Roasted malts and nuts. Rather subdued bitterness. Very candy-like. 090410

Bottle from the legendary Cigar city, shared by the legendary plovmand. In the legendary beershop Ølbutikken on an ordinary wednesday afternoon. Thanks for sharing, Thomas.
Clear brown, small smooth light brown head.
Sweet toffee vanilla aroma. Flavor is strong, toffee, dark caramel, vanilla, faint citrussy hops to balance.
Unfortunately for me, im not very much into brown ale, and not very much into toffee, but the quality shines through anyway.

1 L bottle, courtesy of plovmand. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan and creamy head. Aroma is vanilla and roasted malt. Dark roasted and distinct vanilla flavoured. Distinct chocolate and vanilla flavoured into a dry malty finish.

Growler in Ølbutikke - Thanks Plovmand! Pours a clear brown with a small off-white head. Very sweet with loads of coacoa and vanilla aromas. Also hints of metals towards the. Medium to full bodied. Medium carbonation. Sweet vanilla sugary finish. Too sweet.

Growler. Thanks Hopscotch! Brown body with a creamy tan head. The aroma is chocolate, vanilla, lots of caramel and oak. The flavour is sweet caramel, vanilla, oak, some fruit and light chocolate. Medium bodied.

Growler generously shared by plovmand at Ølbutikken. Very appreciated! 
Pours a mahogany colour with a beige head. 
It has a sweet chocofant (caramel and light chocolate) aroma with vanilla notes. 
The flavour is sweet with light chocolate and vanilla sugar notes on a caramel base. Nice mouthful but to the sweet.

Draft at rattle n hum for cigar city event. Poured a dark brown body with minor lacing. Aroma is strong vanilla, cinnamon, some other spices. Mouthfeel is a bit thinner than preferred but with great flavors of vanilla, oatmeal raisin cookies, cinnamon.
On draft at Rattle n Hum. Pours a dark mahogany colour with no head. Aroma of malt. Flavour of vanilla, chocolate, nuts, and coffee.

32 oz. growler via trade with smith4498 - Pours a clear brown color with a good size light tan head that lasts awhile.  Aroma is toasted caramel malt and faint chocolate.  Flavor is caramel malt, chocolate, and vanilla.  All flavors linger in the finish.  Medium body.  A good beer.  Thanks Jason.

32 oz. growler poured at CCB via trade with smith4498- thanks, Jason!  Pours a cloudy dark brown color with a finger-thick tan head that dissipates and leaves almost nothing.  Aroma starts with a big hit of vanilla, a whole lot of it, with notes of roasted malts, brown sugar, and caramel.  Very sweet smell that mellows as the glass goes down.  I loved it.  The flavor is no surprise after the aroma, plenty of vanilla, with roasted malts, brown sugar, and caramel, as well as some of the tobacco, nutty, and earthy notes that are much more noticeable in the regular Maduro.  The body on this is way too thin and watery, though; with some carbonation and a thicker body, this could have been awesome.  As it stands, the flavor starts with a punch of vanilla, gets progressively roastier, and then dies quickly and weakly because of the thin body.  This could be because I had a growler shipped to me and it lost a little, but I drank it as quickly as I could after receiving it.  Still a pretty cool beer, and I love vanilla and barrel-aged beers, so its right up my alley.

from a 32 oz growler.....pours dark brown some red specks and a medium frothy beige head.  Aroma is full of oats and chocolate malt with a nice backbone of vanilla.  Rich roasty coffee and chocolate, thin vanilla, and a burnt sugar finish.  I enjoy the vanilla being more refined and not overpowering.  Lots of creamyness and medium to thick mouthfeel.

From 32oz Growler. Pours a dark brown with a beige head. Nose is full of vanilla, roasted malts and slight sweetness. Flavors are the same as the nose with vanilla up front then the dark roast and coffee flavors in the finish. Light/Medium body and easy drinking. Yummy stuff.

Draft.  Medium tan head atop dark brown body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some raisin, light vanilla.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some vanilla, raisin, light cola.  Medium body, rather drinkable.

growler.  aroma is soft vanilla that immediately refers to a bowl of melted ice cream.  appearance is ruby/brown with fine head and big legs.  flavor is huge, soft, coating vanilla.  at times as much hershey syrup as it is vanilla.  brown ale roast improves in contrast to the candy sweetness.  cushion, pillow soft mouthfeel.  absolutely addictive.  might be to sweet for some, is suprisingly not cloying for me whatsoever, i could probably slam the whole 32 oz growler of this stuff.
Semi thin body but nice enough to stand the big flavors. Aroma and flavor on this one are great. Smooth, creamy, faint oats and sugar and loads of vanilla. Light toast ans raosted malts, delicious.

Draft at IBG (Lutz, FL).  Served in a wooden keg.  Slightly sweet aroma of vanilla and bourbon.  The flavor was also quite sweet with lots of vanilla along with considerable amount of cherry and a slight oakiness.  Very tasty but a little too sweet for my taste to have more than one in a sitting.

Draft at Rattle N Hum. Solid deep brown body with a smaller white head. The aroma reminded me of the inside of a Dunkin Donuts, artificial vanilla syrup combined with chocolate and coffee notes. Slightly thin body with softer carbonation. The flavor is a combination of vanilla coffee and a chocolate toffee bar. Although this was one of my least favorites of the night its still better then about 90% of the other craft bers out there.
On draft at R & H.  Pours a dark mahogany maple with a small off white head.  Aroma of oats, light vanilla and nuts.  Taste of vanilla, oats and nuts.

A: The pour is a dark brown color with some nice red highlights and a small tan head.

S: A sniff of this one gives you a nosefull of incredibly sweet vanilla. I was expecting some subtlety (a la Stone Smoked Porter with Vanilla), but this is very bold. Theres a slight roasted and toasted malt aroma to this as well.

T: The flavor is almost exactly like the nose. The sweet vanilla is once again the star (as you would expect/hope). There is a slight roasted coffee note to it, along with the same nutty, toasted biscuit malt character that was in the nose.

M: The body is medium with some low to moderate carbonation (probably due to the filling and shipping processes).

D: As previously mentioned, I was expecting just a hint of vanilla, but was actually quite surprised by the amount of vanilla. My only complaint was the level of sweetness that it provided, but otherwise I found it to be quite nice.
Tap at Rattle n Hum.  Vanilla bourbon nose. Medium bodied a bit sweet almost cloying but a good base makes this pretty drinkable.

Tap at Rattle n Hum: Deep amber pour with a fading off white head. Mild toasted barley in the aroma. Coffee-like roast is there with subtle vanilla bean. Slick body. Lots of vanilla in the flavor- but its not that sweet. Some toasted dark crystal malts at the fore precede a touch of subtle coffee-like roast. Balanced with a nice subtle vanilla presence. Solid.

Draft.  Pours a mahogany body with an off white head.  Dark malty sweetness with a creamy vanilla toned body.  Light cream and pie notes and a mild chocolate twist with toast and vanilla.  Great twist on a brown ale.

Tap @ RnH - pours red/brown. raisin, chocolate and vanilla bean. roasty and smoked. finishes dry with some not unpleasant astringency. Sweet and woody, biscuit arouma. Brown and maple sugar. some burnt wood around the edges. Very nice balance. The vanilla really improves the Oatmeal brown ale.
Draft at RnH. Pours brown with a beige head. Sweet malty aroma with some vanilla notes. The flavor has vanilla, light roasty notes and a hint of chocolatey sweetness. Pretty good.

On tap at the Rattle n Hum Cigar City event (thanks John). Deep brown pour with a red hue. Great aroma of vanilla extract, dark chocolate, and oak. More bourbon in the nose as it warms. Flavor has cigar box smokiness, sweet vanilla, and cocoa beans. A really nice roasty finish with a bit of smoke lingering. Cigar City is really twisting some of my previous conceptions of beer because they do a really stellar job of vanilla and bourbon aging.
On tap at CIgar CIty takes NYC event at Rattle N Hum.  Raters at my table were not so oy-yoy-yoy about the vanilla, but I appreciated its edge and smoothness.

On tap at Rattle N Hum for their Cigar City event.   Pours a hazy brown with a thin white head.  Smells like Nesquick, and vanilla.  Creamy and beautiful.  Smooth, sweet and chocolaty. Long smooth vanilla and chocolate on the finish.  Another one I could drink happily all day.

Appearance: Pours a dark red with a little froth.

Aroma: Light vanilla and booze.

Taste: Vanilla beer flavored water.

Mouthfeel: Watery.

Overall: Really not impressed.  The Espresso Maduro is off the charts good, so if given the choice, go with that.

Growler shared by the Tampa crew.  Pours a lightish brown; small beige head. Aroma is sweet vanilla bean as well as some caramel and toffee... but mostly vanilla.  Even more so on taste... like vanilla extract.  If youre looking for vanilla, this is your beer.  Not so complex, though.

One of a million CCB samples shared by the powerful Tampa Crew. Thanks for all the ratings Im about to enter, Greg and Justin! Some of the Maduros Ive had can be on the thinner, lighter side, and this is certainly one of them. Decent enough malty brown ale character at base, but the nose gives away a relative one-dimensionality here. The vanilla was just a bit too sharp, elbowing other things to the side rather than getting along with the malts.
Thanks to the Tampa crew for sharing!  Brown pour with a thin beige head.  Aroma is roasty with a big blast of vanilla.  Light roast and chocoalte up front finish and aftertaste is ALL vanilla

Pours a light brown with a thing light tan head. Nose is sweet, malty, caramel, super vanilla presence, tad one dimensional. Flavor shows lots of vanilla, sweet, some grain astringency. Sweet palate. Vanilla dominated overall.
Growler from CCB.This stuff is great, its my favorite flavored Maduro so far. The vanilla is definitely but its not over powering.

So wonderful to find this one on draught at Cigar City Brewing (Tampa, FL): Pours amber brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of roasted vanilla bean, soft maple syrup rather than caramel, bitter coffee bean, oak wood, and lots of roasted bitters. Flavors are similar. You can really bite into that malt. Thin body, thick tastes. Alcohol hidden well. Drinkability: Simply put, its the taste of swagger. Rebuy: Yes. #252 on 23012010, DG.
GROWLER COURTESY OF MAR.  POURED DARK BROWN WITH WHITE HEAD.  NICE LACE.  AROMA WAS OF CHERRY, VANILLA, SPICE, AND COFFEE.  FLAVOR WAS OF SOUR CHERRY AND MILD VANILLA.  GOOD BEER.

Growler courtesy of Wilkes from the brewery.  Deep red-brown pour a small light tan head that leaves a ring.  Strong vanilla, caramel and nut aroma.  Taste is a toasty version of the aroma with the vanilla dominating.  Slick and creamy (if its possible) medium texture.  Havent had the regular Maduro yet to compare it to  - didnt knock my sock off, but good.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 2010-04-10, growler at Papsø, 6-4-6-3-12=31Dark amber to brown color; clear. Aroma of caramel and vanilla candies. Vanilla chocolate flavor, some roasted malts, smooth mouthfeel. Not impressive.2009-10-17, draught at New Beers Distributors, New York, 6-4-7-3-14=34Hazy brown color. The aroma is quite dusty. Caramel flavor, dry initially, more full bodied later. Correct bitterness, no vanilla. Good Brown Ale, nothing special.

Draft sample at Cigar City. Poured a clear brown color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted malt and dark vanilla aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy cocoa and vanilla sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration. Solid complex brew.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 Bottle thanks to mar.  The look is clear, light brown in color, with a light beige colored head.  The smell is coffee, vanilla, sweet, and caramel.  The taste is roasty, malts, sweet, and caramel.
Bottle thanks to mar. Brown in color with a small off-white head. Aroma is of vanilla, roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is of vanilla, caramel and chocolate.
(Growler, courtesy of Mar)  Pours an amber-brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of vanilla extract, cocoa, caramel, and nuts.  Flavor of grass, roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate, and caramel.
(Growler thanks to mar) Pours clear light brown with no head. Smell of vanilla beans, taste is strongly of vanilla extract and alcohol. Some tobacco notes too. Under carbonated, smoky dry finish too.

growler thanks to mar.  i think my ratings on this were a little harsh.  i remember it being better than my rating reflects.  dont ask me why.  poured a ruby color with an off white head and some spotted lacing.  aroma of caramel, toasted grains, vanilla, and a nutty character.  flavor followed the nose very well with the addition of some nice bittering.  palate had a pleasant dryness to it.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2010 
Name: Maduro Brown, Vanilla
Date: June 26, 2009
Mode: Growler
Source: Tasting
Appearance: clear brown, scant head
Aroma: sweet vanilla and chocolate aroma
Flavor: sweet chocolate and vanilla flavor, vanilla adds a lot of sweetness and complements the chocolate, light balancing bitterness

Name: Maduro Brown, Vanilla
Date: June 11, 2010
Mode: growler
Source: tasting
another good batch, 

Name: Maduro Brown, Vanilla
Date: August 03, 2010
Mode: growler
Source: brewery
Aroma: sweet chocolate and vanilla aroma
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, just a touch of vanilla sweetness leaves it mostly dry

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: **+ /4

@dmacs UFC100 Gathering 1QT growler/hipothicary jarpours a thin light tan head and deep red color.  Aroma is vanilla, sweet medium malt-toffee, earthy.  Taste is vanilla, sweet medium malt-toffee, earthy/spice hops bite.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2009 32oz growler shared by kp at the Brick Store, tasted side-by-side with the Espresso Maduro.

Pours a deep, clear copper brown with a short-lived bubbly tan head that recedes to a small ring leaving very little lacing.

The aroma is much sweeter than the original Maduro and the vanilla really shines through in tandem with the underlying caramel malts.  The hops are less prevalent than in the original as well, but the signature tobacco aroma can still be detected in the nose.

The taste is close to the aroma and starts out very sweet with the vanilla, caramel and chocolate carrying the front of the taste.  There is a toasted malt backbone that shows through in the middle, though the sweetness has overrun it a bit and the finish is slightly dry with the tobacco and some nuts coming out.

The mouthfeel is very smooth with low carbonation, probably due to the growler.  Its fairly full bodied.

This is another solid offering from CCB though I probably prefer the original Maduro to this one.  Its definitely sweeter and less roasty, but this coffee-lover prefers the espresso version in the head-to-head as well.

Growler from sebletitje.  Thanks!  Poured cleark dark brown with a nice white head.  Aroma of vanilla, caramel, chocolate, wood, nuts.  Taste is vanilla, sweet malt, nut, light wood, light citrus hop.  Finish is dry and lightly bitter.  Very well done.

Poured a clear amber color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla, caramel malts, nuts., toast, toffee, and wood.  Taste of vanilla, caramel malts, nuts, a bit of citrus, and a dry finish.

Growler from CCB. Pours a dark brown color with a khaki hue and a small, foamy tan colored head. Some spots of lacing are left behind in the glass. The aroma shows the caramel and chocolate malt base with hints of toasted nuts, marshmellows, and vanilla bean. Pretty sweet smelling. The flavor follows suit with the caramel and chocolate coming through and then quickly followed by the vanilla beans and marshmellows. The vanilla really changes the complexion and quells the roasty elements of the other versions. I really like the flavor the vanilla beans add to this beer. Medium body and smooth with just the right amount of carbonation with the vanilla sweetness left behind. This is another really solid brown ale.

Growler sample at Muckfest 2009 Day 2.  Pours a clear amber/light brown with a thin tan head.  Malty aroma with caramel and a ton of vanilla.  Lots of vanilla flavor up front with a semi-tart caramel finish.  A lot more like the espresso version than the cacao version in terms of subtlety (as in there is none).  Not bad, but theres no question that the espresso is my favorite of the bunch (having not tasted the cedar aged).

Thanks to daknole for shipping a grower to me and a Huge thanks to elnadeau for helping recarbonate after the shipping company caused some leakage.

reddish brown pour, vanilla in the nose and flavor, although the flavor was like the vanilla in a cream soda, rather than a more natural vanilla, it was a tasty beer. I didnt get the smoothness on the palate that oatmeal usually adds.  All in all,  a good beer.

Growler from the brewery. Im actually sampling this before the regular Maduro. Pours a deep brownish-amber color with a thin tan creamy head. Aroma shows toasty malt, caramel, vanilla and brown sugar. Flavors are subtle traces of chocolate, toasty caramel and almond, and of course lots of vanilla but its not overly done and works well with the base. Theres a nice dose of balancing bitter hops that finishes this off nicely. Perhaps not quite as exciting as with some other Cigar City beers but this is a Brown Ale, and a very good one at that.
growler thanks to daknole.  deep brown with a cream head.  nose is creamy vanilla and caramel.  great on the palate with a smooth vanilla that only gets better on every sip.

Growler courtesy of mar.  Clear ruby appearance.  Light aroma.  Hints of dark malts but I am at a loss for the vanilla.  Oh, there it is.  Taste is HUGE vanilla.  Lucky Charms in a bottle.  Great taste that is sweet and smooth.

32oz growler thanks to hopscotch.  Pours a nice amber brown with thin off-white head, larger bubbles move to a ring around the side, decent lacing.  Aroma is very strong of vanillla, maybe a bit overboard, caramel, almonds, and decent malt.  Flavor is absolutely dominated by vanilla and in my opinion just doesnt lend that well to this brew.  Drinkable and enjoyable, just not my combination for a nice brown.

Tap at Cigar City.  Brown pour.  Aroma is nutty and full of vanilla and caramel malt.  Flavor is very nice.  The vanilla melds well with the caramel malt and nutiness of the beer.   So smooth and nice.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 Growler thanks to ibrew2or3, you are the man Dave! Opened with a large pop, and pours a deep brown/amber color with a medium beige, almost orange head. The aroma is very nice; coffee, rich caramel, lots of malts and light vanilla. The flavor is very easygoing and tasty; lots of toasted malts, light toasted almonds, lots of vanilla, but in now way does the vanilla compete  with the other flavors. A easy beer to drink 30 ounces of. Tasty and nice. My first from Cigar City, hopefully one of many.

Growler from the brewery: Pours a transparent dark amber mahogany with a thin, wispy-lacing white head.  Aroma of sweet toasty caramel malts, some nutty notes and a touch of vanilla.  Body starts with pretty good fullness and some mild dark caramel sweetness drying out revealing some earthy hoppy bitterness and vanilla flavor before a bittersweet toasty nutty finish.  A pretty good brown ale.

One of my favorites from CCB.  Pours brown with a medium white head.  Aromas of vanilla take over and drag you into tasting it.  First sip is killer with a beautiful symphony of vanilla and choc oats.  Amazing brew.

Muchas thanks to Alan for sending the 32oz growler!!  Poured clear, garnety-brown with a loose-bubbled cap of beige head.. color and clarity were great, and Ill attribute the slight lack of carbo to the bottle.  The aroma picked up syrupy caramel, molasses, and nutty notes accented by a serious dose of sweet, fresh vanilla bean.. the vanilla was the dominant character with warmth, and it helped create a very desserty impression.  The flavor was almost entirely about the vanilla with a fresh, beany character.. aged caramel, toasted grains, and a pinch of sweeter chocolate at the core.. finished long with more of the vanilla.  Very sweet on the palate with light-to medium body to it.. carbonation was light (again the bottle probably had something to do with it).. balance was quite solid.  Excellent brew with just a little too much vanilla impression.

32oz Growler thanks to hopscotch.
Pours a somewhat clear reddish brown with a thick foamy off white head. That same nose of the traditional maduro, with dark rich nuttiness, caramel and some subtle notes of vanilla. Its not as in your face as I was expecting which is good with a beer this low in alcohol. Slightly watery body but it is a brown ale after all so I cant fault that, toasted almonds ands light chocolate up front with a soft caramel backbone, big juicy vanilla notes towards the end and a light bitterness to keep everything in balance. My favorite version of my favorite brown ale. Awesome!

Growler from the brewery. Pours a dark reddish brown with a thin off white head. Aroma of roasted grain, coffee and vanilla beans. The vanilla bean becomes more dominant as it warms. Taste is roasted grain and smooth vanilla bean with hints of chocolate. I find the vanilla to be much more complimentary to the taste of the brown ale. I know others preferred the espresso version of this, but I found this subtle and delicious and my favorite of the two.

Growler Cloudy brown ale with a small, fat-bubbled, off-white head. Nutty, vanilla, chocolaty nose. Full-bodied and creamy with gentle carbonation. Full-flavored with lots of vanilla, chocolate and toasted nuts. Well-balanced. Sweet, but adequately bittered. Crisp, vanilla finish. I love vanilla beans.

I enjoyed a couple growlers of this, thanks to Cheeseman for picking them up.  Pours brown with just a whispy white head.  Carbonation seems a little lower on this.  Aroma is strong vanilla.  Pure vanilla beans.  Nice.  Flavor is similar to the original Maduro Brown.  Lots of roast and nuttiness.  The vanilla only hits in the finish.  This is good, but I prefer the espresso version.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 Courtesy of nothernbrews
Growler:  The aroma consists of vanilla, chocolate, and roasted nuts.  It pours a transparent mahogany with a small off-white head that quickly fades to a very thin ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with chocolate and lots of vanilla that builds into the finish.  The finish also has roasted nuts and a hint of caramel.  Light bodied with minimal carbonation and a thin mouthfeel.

Growler courtesy GodofThunder. Ruby color with a light head. Touch of vanilla in the nose with a touch of woodiness and tobacco makes it come across almost like a dipped cigar. But the strong vanilla flavor comes across like vanilla creme soda mixed with brown ale, not crazy about it, but vanilla isnt my favorite. Easy finish.

thanks to the cheeseman for bring this one back from tampa!  Vanilla with heavy caramel aroma, sweet cafe au lait aromas.  Pours brown with no head.  Definitely sweeter than the normal Maduro, strong vanilla flavors with thick caramel malts, light coffee flavors with a slightly nutty finish.  Excellent beer!

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 Growler from the brewery, just hours old.  The pour yields a dark, chestnut colored body that glows translucent at the edges.  A small, tight head of khaki colored foam leaves wet, jagged lines and micro-spots of lacing behind on the glass.  The nose is sweeter than the other versions of Maduro that I have tried, the vanilla lending a sort of "root beer" like feel to the underlying caramel and cocoa malt, with subtle hints of brown sugar glazed nuts.   Flavors follow suit, considerably less roasty than the other versions, sweet from the vanilla and dark caramel.  The chocolate component also seems to be subdued, overpowered by notes of toasted marshmallow, vanilla, and powdered sugar.  Just a hint of roasted coffee hits the back of the throat.  Medium bodied and smooth, the perceived sweetness makes this one just a shade less sessionable than its brethren, but it still feels nice on the tongue.  Another very solid brown ale from CCB, though this is probably my least favorite version of Maduro.

On tap at a CCB event at Brass Tap (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown with reddish highlights. Aroma is sweet and malty with lots of vanilla and notes of chocolate, roast, brown sugar, nuts and caramel. Flavor is also sweet and malty with notes of vanilla, chocolate, coffee, wood, molasses, caramel and some hints of brown sugar and nuts. Medium body with a pleasing malty finish. A really easy drinking beer that would be great all night.

On tap @ The Brass Tap: Pours an amber brown with an off-white head that is mostly lasting. Vanilla is very evident in the roasty aroma and flavor with hints of caramel and chocolate malts. Has a medium body and creamy texture that is smooth and sweet in the finish. I prefer the normal Maduro Oatmeal Brown Ale. However, this is a nice twist on a very good recipe.

Tap. Pours a slightly hazy brown with amber highlights. Vanilla is huge in the nose with roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Taste is chocolate, light roasted malt, coffee, and just a hint of vanilla in the finish. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness. Very good but if Cigar City combined the Vanilla Maduro and Espresso Maduro it would be a match made in heaven.

On tap at Brass tap. Murky brown, thin head. Immediately chocolate nose, then i realized it was the vanilla and dark malts melding to create this vanilla/chocolate ice cream nose. Flavors of smoke, vanilla, some roast, tobacco, cocoa, earth and mild bitterness. Has that signature, full body that all CCB beers have. Excellent offering! I could drink this all night.

Poured at Brass Tap.  RATING#800.  Incredible beer.  Pours red-amber with a small off-white head.  Nose is some tobacco, malt, and some sugar with mellow vanilla cruising throughout this incredible beer.  Flavor is toasted malt, tobacco, mellow vanilla, and bits of caramel.  Like the Espresso Maduro, the Vanilla sings along in harmony, but does not overly dominate any of the sonata.  I loved this beer.  Body was light to medium, and the finish was a nice blend of sweet vanilla, very mild bitter, and malts.

Poured up on tab at the 05/28/09 Brass Tap CCB tasting with a slightly hazy brown  amber body and nice looking lasting tan head with spotty lacing. The aroma is sweet with malts, vanilla and a dash of caramel. Overall the aroma is moderate in strength and is able to bend the will of the drinker to go ahead and take a sip even if youre not ready. The taste is much roastier then the nose and is tempered by the smooth near creamy oatmeal-ness. It begins with mild vanilla and caramel notes before layers upon layer of roast to dark roastiness take over. The vanilla persists in the background and build some into the finish. It ends a bit roasty dry but with lingering vanilla sweetness.

Draft at Brass Tap.  Poured a dark reddish brown with a very thin egg-shell head.  Aroma is full of strong sweet Madagascar vanilla, tobacco, and chocolate malt.  Flavor is heavy with vanilla but not overpowering in my opinion.  I could still taste the chocolate malt, toffee, and coffee flavors peeking thru.  My favorite spin-off of Maduro so far.

Pours a standard medioum brown with a small amount of head that quickly fades away.  Aroma of toasted marshmellow on a cup of hot chocolate.  The flavor is delicte and complex.  Hints of chocolate, malt and mild coffee surfaces behind a strong vanilla attack.  The beer was a little thin but that helps lend this to a more sessionable ale.  I think this needs to apper as a 750

On draft at Brass Tap!

A: Pours more amber than the normal nutty brown hue of standard maduro. Nice creamy head that only manages ok retention. Some nice lace does form on the glass.

S: The nose is nice with vanilla dominating. Very light notes of chocolate and coffee as well, but mostly vanilla.

T: Bold fresh vanilla bean right from the start. Nothing artifical here. Barely hiding beneath the vanilla is a bit of chocolate, oats and earth.

M: On the lighter side of medium, good carbonation.

D: Ok, lots of vanilla keeps me at one or two pints. Tasty, but not quite as good as the Espresso Maduro I had a few nights ago at Datz.
